Metadata: {"YelpName": "Feinstein's at the Nikko", "AuthorName": "Magda G.", "AuthorLocation": "San Francisco, CA"}

ReviewContent: Impressed with this venue - intimate, good acoustics, and you can reach out and touch the performers, they are that close. Seating is not cramped with good sight lines for all seats from what I could tell. Actually, I think the seats in the very front are too close. Service was fine except waited for almost an hour for a coffee and cup of tea that finally came 5 minutes before showtime. I'm not giving it 5 stars because it's pricey. The $20 food/drink minimum is too high for the choices and portion size, then add 18% and cost of tickets and you're looking at a lot of money for only an hour-15 minute show. The highlight definitely, was the fabulous Paula West! And the musicians! I'd say come here for a very special performer but not for a regular night out.
Metadata: {"YelpName": "Feinstein's at the Nikko", "AuthorName": "Helen Y.", "AuthorLocation": "San Rafael, CA"}

ReviewContent: A nice update for a classy space. Went to hear the amazing Paula West sing there on Valentine's Day and couldn't have been happier by the service or the music. The person who seated us was very pleasant and even suggested to my friend and I that we sit on the bar seats toward the back which a) had a better view and b) gave us more room than sitting at a table. Tickets were reasonable at $35 each (will call) and there is a $20 per person drink minimum once the show began. I had a coffee with various liquors added along with a shot of Maker's Mark. Yummy! They were so busy that it took awhile to have our server take our drink orders, but she was very apologetic and we had great service during the show.
Metadata: {"YelpName": "Feinstein's at the Nikko", "AuthorName": "David G.", "AuthorLocation": "San Francisco, CA"}

ReviewContent: Very nice venue....you can sit anywhere and be fine, so don't think you have to pay for the "front of house" tickets. While I'm not a fan of imposed drink/food minimums, I get it......and I will say that the drink I was having was not horribly priced.....the coffee with two kinds of alcohol. Very enjoyable and I think $7. So I could have 3 and fulfill my minimum :-)
Metadata: {"YelpName": "Feinstein's at the Nikko", "AuthorName": "Laurie H.", "AuthorLocation": "Oakland, CA"}

ReviewContent: So excited that there is a small, intimate venue for great musical talent. Just saw the amazing Betty Buckley. Tickets w/seats "up front" --$80 pp plus the usual service charge for the tickets.then tack on the $20pp minimum for food or drinks and as they say repeatedly on the website "for your convenience" they have decided the gratuity will be 18 percent. For goodness sake, I'm a big person and I can decide what I choose to tip based on  the level of service. Loved the show but again it was an hour and 15 minutes, max. Somehow feel a bit gyped.
Metadata: {"YelpName": "Feinstein's at the Nikko", "AuthorName": "Jane V.", "AuthorLocation": "San Francisco, CA"}

ReviewContent: I went here to see Tony DeSare back in October, and I couldn't have been more pleased with the venue. It was small and intimate, and the seats were all arranged for a good view of the stage. Seating was first-come, first-served (unless you ate at the restaurant upstairs, which allowed you to reserve a seat earlier), but arriving when the doors opened (about an hour before the show) allowed us to get a great seat right in front.  It was a great view of Tony DeSare's impressive piano technique (which involved reaching inside the piano at times). I can honestly say I've never been to a serious concert venue that made it so easy to be so close.The food and drinks were great, with very reasonable prices and a surprising amount of selection given that it was mostly just appetizers and desserts. There were at least 4-5 options on the menu that were suitable for vegetarians, and I think one of the dishes was either vegan or very close to it. If that's important to you, definitely call ahead to verify. The staff was friendly, and I didn't feel like there were any surprises in terms of fees/food minimums. It was made very clear on the ticketing website that there was a $20 minimum per person, which is reasonable even if you don't drink alcohol. In terms of sound, Feinstein's was perfect. There were curtains and low ceilings and you didn't get that annoying echo some places have. It was cozy, intimate, and everything was performed at the perfect volume. I would definitely go back if someone else I wanted to see was performing there.
Metadata: {"YelpName": "Feinstein's at the Nikko", "AuthorName": "Stefanie H.", "AuthorLocation": "Sacramento, CA"}

ReviewContent: A drastically different experience from a few months ago. I was so impressed with this place when we came in May; I could hardly believe I was in the same place. The service at our pre-show dinner upstairs was mediocre at best. The waiter forgot the last course of our pre-fixe meal and served up our check instead. Oh, and apparently our tickets don't include the $30 food and drink credit they used to, so our bill was $200. Then our bill downstairs during the show was another $100 because, as the very snippy waitress said as she snatched up my card, "there's a $20 minimum like I told you more than once." which is silly if you're a non-drinker who isn't thrilled at the idea of paying again for a dessert you'd already paid for upstairs.Keep your divas, even Linda Eder couldn't out diva our rude waitress. I won't be back here. Next time I'll sit in the lobby and listen quite contentedly.
Metadata: {"YelpName": "Feinstein's at the Nikko", "AuthorName": "Ty A.", "AuthorLocation": "Seattle, WA"}

ReviewContent: I wish I liked this place better because I love listening to great music in small intimate venues. On our recent visit, the music was excellent, but the seats we were given were much worse than expected even though we were among the first to arrive. Better seating is given to those dining at Anzu. Because I am not a fan of Anzu, I had a bad seat and ate from the mediocre and crazy overpriced for super small portions bar menu. In the end, the great musical performance did not compensate for the uncomfortable vibe. I will not be going back, but If you go, make sure you understand how not to be stuck at a bad seat, eat before you go, and only go for the music.
Metadata: {"YelpName": "Feinstein's at the Nikko", "AuthorName": "Ed C.", "AuthorLocation": "San Francisco, CA"}

ReviewContent: Went to see Oleta Adams at Feinsteins last night.  First time there.  Let's start with ambiance.  Dark somber room (I guess this is supposed to be elegance?)  No art on the walls, just a dark curtain as a backdrop and the stage.  The space is definitely small and intimate.  Fits maybe 100 people.  Service was great.  Hostess was very friendly.  So was waitress.  Menu:  Here's the catch.  On top of the cover charge, there is a $20 minimum food and beverage charge.  So, you have to order food and/or drinks.Drinks: LOTS of drinks to choose from.  Specialty drinks, fine wines, beers etc.  Wines range from about $9 a glass to about $375 a glass and everything in between.  (Can get bottles too.) Specialty drinks are about $13, beers are $6.  So for drinkers, lots of choice.  Also, tea and coffee.  My wife and I don't drink so we can't comment on the drinks other than what we saw on the menu.  Food:  They have some variety.  We calculated $40 worth of food and ordered accordingly.  For $40 we got:  A Margherite Pizza (wife liked it).  An olive plate (nice mix of olives, quite a few), Cheese plate with 4 types of cheese, some crackers and apple slices and Pork Ribs.  The pork ribs were not exciting because the sauce was not very good.  But the cheese was tasty as were the olives.  By the way, Oleta Adams was great.  Definitely a class act.  She gets 4 stars.  So, why only 3 stars to the venue?  Well, mostly because it's pricey.  We got our tickets through goldstar so we only paid a little over 1/2 price.  So tickets for 2 were $60.  Then there's the $40 minimum.  They include an 18% gratuity automatically (not too fond of that move - although we always tip in the 15-20% range anyways if the service is good. Just like to have the option to not tip as well if the service is lacking - which it wasn't).  So total food bill with gratuity and tax turned out to be about $52.   Total for the night for 2 people was $92 dollars.  That's more than we usually spend but, what the hell, once in a while you have to splurge a little.  If there's an artist that you really want to see, then it's worth it.  Too expensive for a casual hang out unless you're rolling in dough.  The sound in the place was great.  I noticed there's a lot of cabaret type acts that play there so if that's you're thing and you can afford it, you might just love the place.
Metadata: {"YelpName": "Feinstein's at the Nikko", "AuthorName": "X Y.", "AuthorLocation": "Castro Valley, CA"}

ReviewContent: Great spot in the City. Intimate room. I've been a couple of times since it became Feinstein's. Sutton Foster was terrific, and at 85, Barbara Cook was also amazing. I'm really looking forward to Linda Eder.
Metadata: {"YelpName": "Feinstein's at the Nikko", "AuthorName": "Steven M.", "AuthorLocation": "Financial District, San Francisco, CA"}

ReviewContent: This is a great venue with a great atmosphere!Go check it out! =)
Metadata: {"YelpName": "Feinstein's at the Nikko", "AuthorName": "April R.", "AuthorLocation": "San Francisco Bay Area, CA"}

ReviewContent: Such a small space, used to be the Rrazz Room, great venue. We've been here twice since rebranding, last night Christine Ebersole, a great performer. Service is haphazard, drinks a little light, desserts a little heavy. Under no circumstance should you let them seat you at Table 49. This is the worst table in the room. You will have lights glaring in your eyes, and a lousy view. Come for the show. Enjoy!
Metadata: {"YelpName": "Feinstein's at the Nikko", "AuthorName": "William M.", "AuthorLocation": "San Francisco, CA"}

ReviewContent: What an amazing venue. The space is incredibly intimate and the service is excellent. I went with a small group and sat very close to the stage. The sound, atmosphere and ambiance are premier and the drinks are exceptional. I honestly can't think of one thing these folks do wrong. I plan to return for date night.
Metadata: {"YelpName": "Feinstein's at the Nikko", "AuthorName": "Isaac C.", "AuthorLocation": "San Jose, CA"}

ReviewContent: Love the space they have here. They make you feel like a pimp in the zone.  The performers are in your lap and it feels like they might be in your living room. It set me back a few bucks but it was totally worth the dollars. you gotta spend it to make it ho!
Metadata: {"YelpName": "Feinstein's at the Nikko", "AuthorName": "Dru P.", "AuthorLocation": "Lafayette, IN"}

ReviewContent: I love this place. It's a rare treat in the city to be able to have such an intimate setting for a show. I saw modern day TorchSinger Spencer Day there a few months ago, and it was a great performance. Literally not a bad seat in the house. They have a wide variety of acts coming in, with a specific focus on Broadway performers, contemporary musicians and fans of the Great American Songbook. The service was really attentive, and I really enjoyed my dinner from the upstairs restaurant, Anzu. The ceviche was some of the best I've had, my only complaint is that there wasn't more of it on my plate. Before the show we sat in their lounge area called and had some delicious happy hour food. The wings are delicious. Really. For me, being able to see musicians and performers in an intimate, classy setting-- is well worth the extra loot spent.  I'll be back!
Metadata: {"YelpName": "Feinstein's at the Nikko", "AuthorName": "Krista N.", "AuthorLocation": "San Pedro, CA"}

ReviewContent: Excellent venue with first class performances. Perfect social spaces, amazing for date nights and celebrations. Good to go.
Metadata: {"YelpName": "Feinstein's at the Nikko", "AuthorName": "Christopher L.", "AuthorLocation": "Oakland, CA"}

ReviewContent: Expensive.  Additional charges are $8.25 per ticket and 18% gratuity and sales tax.  All in all a very expensive evening.  Why not go to a Broadway show or a show at ACT or Berkeley Rep?Must better value for your money.  I will not return.
Metadata: {"YelpName": "Feinstein's at the Nikko", "AuthorName": "Richard H.", "AuthorLocation": "San Rafael, CA"}

ReviewContent: As a long time attendee of the Rrazz Room, I am very happy Michael Feinstein took control of this wonderful space and that it did not sit empty for long, especially with the closing of the Rrazz Room soon after their move.  Feinstein's has made some wonderful cosmetic improvements with the outside bar and entrance area.  The black curtain replacing the white curtain across the back of the stage is a nice cosmetic improvement as well.  Don't let the higher ticket prices get you down...while it seems shocking at first, each ticket comes with a $30 Anzu or showroom credit.  I don't find the menu prices have increased at all, and like that I've all ready put $30 per ticket towards my bill.  Feinstein's doesn't pack the room the way the previous occupants did.  We've been to Feinstien's twice now, and commented that four of us were comfortably seated in a space that would have been cramped in the past.  The seats were perfect...until the two tall guys came alone five minutes before the show started and completely blocked my view for the entire show....it's definitely worth paying the extra $10 per person to not have that happen. Additionally, it appears the staff have been trained to be less intrusive during the show.  While the staff used to flutter about constantly, doing their jobs, often now I see a flood of staff come through in between songs, being less obtrusive to both the patrons and performers.  I noticed this great change immediately!  I'm also pleased to find they've employed some of the previous venue's wait staff.The only reason I did not give this five stars is that I was a club member of the Rrazz, and always had the same perfect seats at every show, and didn't have to fight the crowd for a seat, so I guess I'm a little spoiled in this space.  I hope Feinstein's will offer up something like that very soon.  You can reserve your seat if you eat at Anzu's first....but their menu has never been appealing to us  in all the years we've been attending shows at the hotel.This is my favorite venue to see a show. Period.  The space is intimate, the sound is fantastic and 99% of the time performers sign autographs and pose for photographs afterwards.  Thank you Feinstein's for keeping the wonderful nightclub tradition alive in San Francisco, I was really feeling lost without it!
Metadata: {"YelpName": "Feinstein's at the Nikko", "AuthorName": "Steele C.", "AuthorLocation": "San Francisco, CA"}

ReviewContent: Great management now for this nightclub. Feinstein's is a welcome change from the Rrazz Room, where only the gay male couples got decent seats and the rest of us got the leftovers. Rude managers/owners came west and brought their nastiness with them (giving the nice people from New Jersey a very bad name). Last time I was at Rrazz Room, they sat me so far over to the side that I could see the back of the performer's head. Right before the show started, they put up a Big Amplifier Box right in front of me and then I couldn't even see the back of the performer's head. Too late to make a scene because show was starting, so I waited until afterward and talked to one of the Jersey boys -- he couldn't have been ruder and completely blew me off. Then the Nikko blew Jersey off (who's got the rrazz now?) and Feinstein's came in. Different demographics scattered throughout the club, not crammed in like sardines as we were when Rrazz ruled, and respect for their paying guests. Enjoyed Spencer Day tonight (he'll be there 5/25 too)... a modern day torch singer who's very talented and clever. Thanks Feinstein's for making this into a great nightclub, just what we needed in SF.
Metadata: {"YelpName": "Feinstein's at the Nikko", "AuthorName": "Cydney B.", "AuthorLocation": "Vancouver, WA"}

ReviewContent: I really wanted to give Feinstein's five stars, and hopefully will as they iron out the kinks in their new location.  It looks gorgeous, simpler and yet more elegant than The Rrazz Room did.  It is expensive and there are a lot of charges first time visitors may be surprised by, but service was good, sight lines were not.  All tickets come with a $30.00 food/beverage credit which is a smooth move.  The staff seemed eager to provide a great experience and although struggling with a lot of tables, our server was excellent.  One note that was troubling and disconcerting was a  handful of customers who were overserved and interrupted the show with loud, bellicose comments to the performer.  It was funny a few times, but it got obnoxious quickly and no one seemed willing or able to quiet the guys.  Sound was good, lighting a great improvement, food was small portioned but tasty and our table was too small for the food and beverage we ordered, so thank God we were seated early enough that we could 'borrow' the empty table next to us.  The banquet we sat on was very uncomfortable and our backs were in agony by the time the show was over.  One commonly expressed complaint we heard is the way the front of house staff tell everyone that asks for better seating that the room is 'sold out' and changes can't be made.  After hearing that a dozen or more times, the people loudest got moved while several tables weren't even used and others had quite a few empty seats.  I've owned and operated a lot of restaurants and clubs and I know the value of good seating, but I truly believe one of the things that killed The Rrazz Room was their handling of guest seating.  I hope Feinstein's works through these tiny glitches and becomes the great and elegant nightclub San Francisco deserves.
Metadata: {"YelpName": "Feinstein's at the Nikko", "AuthorName": "Stu S.", "AuthorLocation": "San Francisco, CA"}

ReviewContent: Went to the club last Sat. night to see Sutton Foster and had a delightful time. I was not already a fan and now am.     The club looks beautiful and was comfortable with good sight lines. An intimate nightclub for sure. I have many times spent more money at larger venues only to be seated far away. I don't think that is even possible here. I was impressed with the level of service from the staff. They do really seem to be working as a team.   I will be back soon!!
Metadata: {"YelpName": "Feinstein's at the Nikko", "AuthorName": "D. S.", "AuthorLocation": "Fairfax, CA"}

ReviewContent: Great space. Great service. Great performance. So what gives, Feinstein's? Why are you trying to steal my money?We paid 18% gratuity to order tickets online. Then we paid another 18% gratuity for the service. The "front row" seats ($95/each) that we bought came with $30 credit for food and drink, but apparently gratuity and tax is levied separately. One other caution: there is a bottle of Dom Pérignon misprinted on the menu at $30. It is $30 for a glass, not a bottle, duh.(*Update - since writing this, Feinstein's sent an email saying they "heard us." Now every guest must spend a $20 minimum on food and drink. Um. This is better how?)Getting seated was a mess. We came an 1 1/2 hours early because that's when we were told doors would open. The hostess told us they'd start seating in about 15 minutes, which was fine, and we stood over to the side. Fifteen minutes later, when they opened, some other couple had come to check in. Instead of saying something like, "oh, this couple was here before you," the hostess just sat them before us!I came here to see Sutton Foster, who I've been obsessed with for a few years now. She did not disappoint. Neither did the space. It felt a lot like Sutton Foster came to your living room to perform. We still got a booth seat on the floor, and Sutton was amazing. She even hung around afterward in the hotel bar. It really doesn't look like there's a bad seat in the house, but I'd advise against the cheap seats. I think in a full house -- which ours was not -- the number of heads might make it hard to see the performer. There is also only a $20 difference between the worst and best seats in the theater.
Metadata: {"YelpName": "Feinstein's at the Nikko", "AuthorName": "David S.", "AuthorLocation": "San Francisco, CA"}

ReviewContent: Cozy venue, I don't think there are any bad seats in the house.  It's not cheap, but with acts like Sutton Foster I didn't expect it to be a discount show. They have a wide selection of drinks and reduced menu from the restaurant Anzu upstairs, many of the portions aren't very large but they are satisfying. Service tries to keep quite during the performance and do a good job. The seats are fairly comfortable, that's am important thing to me.I like the piano bar just outside, it gives you a great place to hang out when you wait.  If you go for good seats be sure to check in at 5:30~5:45p (for the 8pm show) and reserve a table.I've added myself to their mailing list, I'm going to keep an eye on upcoming shows. If the right act comes back, I'll be there.
Metadata: {"YelpName": "Feinstein's at the Nikko", "AuthorName": "Sean S.", "AuthorLocation": "San Ramon, CA"}

ReviewContent: Very expensive compared to the Rrazz Room.  Ordered  food and it came cold.  Sent it back and it still came cold so we just ate it.Have to figure $100+ per person to see a show.  The show was 65 minutes.  Won't be returning.Poor value for the money.
